awd_titl_txt: ANISOTROPY CHANGES DURING DEFORMATION AND PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS
awd_abstract_narration:
Large regions of the Earth are anisotropic for propagation of seismic waves. This is best understood for the upper mantle where anisotropy is attributed to preferred orientation of olivine crystals, attained during convection. Anisotropy is extreme in sheet-silicate-rich rocks in the crust such as shales and slates, especially important because of the significance for hydrocarbon exploration. It also is present in the lower mantle, particularly the lowermost D" zone at the core-mantle boundary. Much of the anisotropy is caused by deformation and associated alignment of crystals, but the detailed mechanisms in the deep Earth are still poorly understood. This project will explore macroscopic deformation and associated anisotropy development in the Earth by investigating the underlying microscopic mechanisms with novel methods that have become available at National facilities, such as synchrotron X-ray and neutron diffraction, and then applying physical models to project the large picture. The project will provide data that are critical for interpreting macroscopic seismic observations. But research methods that will be advanced are relevant for a broad range of physical sciences as well as engineering. In situ observation of changes during phase transformations has direct application in materials science (e.g. transition metals, high temperature superconductors) and civil engineering (e.g. cement minerals). The experimental methods, data analysis, as well as modeling capabilities will become available to other researchers through interdisciplinary collaborations and disseminated to the scientific community with workshops and training. Participation of students will continue to be an important part of this project.

During the last years the PI and collaborators have performed in situ deformation experiments with diamond anvil cells (DAC) and multi anvil apparatus at the Advanced Light Source (LBL) and the Advanced Photon Source (ANL) on systems such as perovskite, postperovskite and magnesiowuestite, and were able to infer deformation mechanisms by comparing experimental preferred orientation patterns with predictions from polycrystal plasticity theory. When applying the microscopic mechanisms they could propose an explanation for macroscopic seismic anisotropy in D". However, conditions of experiments are still far from the real Earth. They have initiated a program to work at higher temperature and slower strain rates. A major focus is to develop reliable heating techniques for the deformation DAC and apply them to study plastic deformation, recrystallization and phase transitions of high pressure phases. A second focus are polyphase materials whose deformation behavior is still largely enigmatic, for example perovskite (strong)-magnesiowuestite (weak) mixtures. Also here experimental results will be compared with plasticity models. The new full-field fast Fourier transform formulation developed at Los Alamos which takes local interactions between grains into account has great possibilities. While emphasis is on the deep Earth, the PI and his team also plan to pursue recent work on quartz where mechanical twinning and residual stresses are potential paleopiezometers. Preliminary deformation, X-ray microdiffraction and EBSD experiments are promising for not only estimating magnitudes but more importantly the directionality of the stress field.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
A major emphasis was to advance the multigrain method for crystal orientation analysis of multiphase materials that likely dominate most regions in the Earth. This is a collaborative project with Joel Bernier (LLNL) and the core of the PhD theses of Chase Chandler (PhD in May 2021) and Michelle Devoe (awarded an ALS Fellowship for 2022). With multigrain it has been possible to document microstructural changes during transformation of orthorhombic olivine to orthorhombic bridgmanite and cubic ferropericlase at high pressure and temperature, using diamond anvil cells and synchrotron X-ray diffraction (Chandler et al. 2021a, b). Microstructural features involve grain nucleation and growth, preferred orientation, local stress and grain shapes (Fig. 1).

Experiments suggest that preferred orientation in two-phase aggregates with strong and weak phases is much weaker than in corresponding single phases. To understand this we need new plasticity models that take grain interaction into account. Using the finite element method reveals that soft ferropericlase is much less textured than stronger bridgmanite. This started as part of Eloisa Zepeda?s PhD thesis (now at LANL) and continued with collaborations with Paul Dawson (Cornell) and his student Matt Kasemer (now professor at the University of Alabama) (Kasemer et al. 2020).

These new observations have also been incorporated in macroscopic models of slab subduction into the lower mantle (Chandler et al. 2021c) (Fig. 2). In the future dynamic recrystallization needs to be incorporated as a significant deformation mechanism.

A new opportunity has been the use of microfocus Laue diffraction to infer lattice distortions in quartz and to map strain directions to infer tectonic deformation geometry. We have started a systematic investigation of residual strain in deformed metamorphic quartzites from Alpine nappes and observed correlations with crystal preferred orientation patterns in naturally deformed quartzites (Wenk et al. 2020a). In quartzites we can obtain not only pole figures for crystal orientations but as well of strain tensor orientations (Fig. 3). To streamline this method experiments of Laue microdiffraction had to be refined) and data analysis (software such as XMAS and XtalCAMP, Li et al. 2020) had to be updated.

Perhaps most exciting has been the discovery of a new record of texture strength, not in recrystallized metals that previously were frontrunners, but in fine-grained multiphase slate with over 120 multiples of random distribution for muscovite and chlorite (Wenk et al. 2020b, Huang et al. 2021) (Fig. 4). This is attributed to recrystallization under stress. It is most significant for interpreting seismically observed anisotropy in the upper crust.

Another unexpected finding was the documentation of seismic anisotropy in Westerly granite that was for a long time the classical example of an isotropic rock (Lokajicek et al. 2020). This has been explored with ultrasound velocity measurements on spheres, as well as neutron texture analysis.

 

References

Chandler C.B., Bernier J.V., Diamond M., Kunz M., Wenk H.-R. (2021a) Exploring microstructures in lower mantle mineral assemblages with synchrotron x-rays. Science Adv. 7, eabd3614

Chandler, C.B., Devoe, M., Kunz, M., Wenk, H.-R. (2021b) Using multigrain crystallography to explore the microstructural evolution of the a olivine to g ringwoodite transformation and e-Mg2SiO4 at high pressure and temperature. Minerals 11(4), 424

Chandler, C.B., Chen, L., Li, M., Romanowicz, B., Wenk, H.-R. (2021c). Forward modeling seismic anisotropy in the lower mantle through 3-phase aggregate deformation. G.J. Int. 227(3), 1665-1681

Huang, J., Devoe, M., Gomez-Barreiro J., Ren, Y., Vasin, R., Wenk, H.-R. (2021). Preferred orientation and anisotropy of slates from Northern Spain. Int. J. Earth Sci. (submitted).

Kasemer, M., Zepeda-Alarcon, E., Carson, R., Dawson, P., Wenk, H.-R. (2020). Finite element modeling of deformation response of dual phase bridgmanite/periclase with high strength contrast. Acta Mater. 189, 284-298

Li, Y., Chen, K., Zhang, F., Tamura, N., Ku, C.S., Kang, H., Wenk, H.-R. (2020). XtalCAMP: a comprehensive program for the analysis and visualization of scanning Laue X-ray micro/nano-diffraction data. J. Appl. Cryst. 53, 1392-1403

Lokajicek, T., Vasin, R., Svitek, T., Petruzalek, M., Kotrly, M., Turkova, I., Onysko, R., Wenk, H.-R. (2020). Intrinsic elastic anisotropy of Westerly granite observed by ultrasound measurements, microstructural investigations, and neutron diffraction. J. Geophys. Res. Solid Earth 126, e2020JB020878

Wenk, H.-R., Chandler, C.B., Chen, K., Li, Y., Tamura, N., Yu, R (2020). Residual lattice strain in quartzites as a potential paleo-piezometer. Geoph. J. Int. 222, 1363-1378

Wenk, H.-R., Yu, R., Cardenes, V., Lopez-Sanchez, M.A., Sintubin, M (2020). Review: Fabric and anisotropy of slates: From classical studies to new results. J. Struct. Geol. 138, 104066


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Hans-Rudolf Wenk

Images (1 of )
  • Fig. 3. Measuring residual strain in deformed quartzite with microfocus synchrotron Laue diffraction. (a) Optical image, (b) crystal orientation, (c) residual compressive strain tensor axes, (d) Residual strain pole figures.
    H.R. Wenk
    Public Domain
    Hans-Rudolf Wenk
    Fig. 3
  • Fig. 1. Grain spatial and stress/strain distribution at high pressure with multigrain crystallography . (A) 3-d distribution of bridgmanite br and ferropericlase fp grains after 4 heating cycles. Grain colors are % equivalent strain. (B) Average equivalent stress in br (blue) and fp (red).
    Chandler et al. 2021a
    Public Domain
    Hans-Rudolf Wenk
    Fig. 1
  • Fig. 2. Modeling subduction of slab into the lowermost mantle and transformation of perovskite Pv (light grey) to postperovskite pPv (dark grey) in different areas of the slab.Preferred orientation shown in pole figures and elastic wave anisotropy as colored projections.
    Chandler 2021c
    Public Domain
    Hans-Rudolf Wenk
    Fig. 2
